climbs.name: Twist & Crawl
climbs.fa: Wallace & Olson, FFA July 1991 by M. Carter

content.description:
Twist & Crawl is a completely ignored though decent climb.  Maybe the replacement of several nasty bolts and a new anchor with breathe life into this climb.   

  Start in a dihedral that ends on a short section of slab.  At the slab, negotiate a small bulge and you'll be rewarded with a decent stance on a ramp.  Work your way right and into another short dihedral.  At this point the route gets steeper and the climbing gets burly.  Deadpoint to a flat edge on the arÃªte, pull-up into the steep crack above and layback up to the anchor. 

  Taming Twist & Crawl takes a full bag of climbing tricks.  There are several cruxes, each being quite different in style.
content.protection: bolts + (optional) small TCU to back up the piton

content.description: One of the most consistently steep routes at Broughtons, Closet Nazi offers powerful, exciting climbing.  Relative straight forward for the grade, and for a Broughton's route, it is a good 5.12 if you're just getting into the grade.  Once through the mid-section the business is over, but the pump might make you fail near the top.
content.location: Berlin Wall, first route on left.

content.description: This line tackles the large Berlin Wall overhang, with some fun, precise, and quite dirty climbing. Doesn't match the quality of Closet Nazi, but worth a go.A cam or a very long stick clip is recommended for the start.
content.location: Middle of Berlin Wall, right of Twist and Crawl. Look for the large overhang, and start on the slab crack.

content.description: A short cliff between Bat Wall and Jungle Cliff, there are a couple good and powerful and quite steep routes here. The three commonly climbed routes are (Left to Right): C***** N***, 5.12a - Twist and Crawl, 5.11d - and G*******, 5.12d/13a. All are about 45' tall, and feature good bolts and steel sport clip anchors.
